source: Library of Congress, FSA/OWI Black-and-White Negatives
creditLine: Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, FSA/OWI Collection

photos.title: Rear of apartment house with Milwaukee courthouse
photos.caption: The back of an apartment building near the new Milwaukee courthouse — conditions HOLC appraisers would evaluate two years later.

photos.title: Housing under Wisconsin Avenue viaduct
photos.caption: Homes tucked beneath the Wisconsin Avenue viaduct. Living in the shadow of infrastructure, literally.

photos.title: Slum area housing, Milwaukee
photos.caption: Housing in what the government called a 'slum area' — neighborhoods that would be graded D (Hazardous) by HOLC.

photos.title: Rear of houses, Milwaukee
photos.caption: Back alleys revealed what front facades hid. HOLC appraisers noted building conditions as part of their grading.

photos.title: Houses near industrial area, Milwaukee
photos.caption: Residential housing pressed against Milwaukee's industrial zone — proximity to factories lowered HOLC grades.

photos.title: Milwaukee freight yards and industrial plants
photos.caption: Milwaukee's freight yards and factories. Industrial employment drew workers, but living nearby meant lower property values.

photos.title: Street scene, Milwaukee
photos.caption: A Milwaukee street two years before HOLC appraisers would walk these blocks and decide their future.

photos.title: Apartments near 8th and Wisconsin, Milwaukee
photos.caption: Apartment buildings near 8th and Wisconsin Avenue, in the heart of what would become a C-graded zone.

photos.title: House at 437 North Jackson Street, Milwaukee
photos.caption: 437 North Jackson Street. Specific addresses documented by the FSA — many of these buildings are now gone.

photos.title: Alley and houses at 1012 West Somers Street
photos.caption: Looking down the alley at 1012 West Somers Street. Alleys were gathering places and sometimes the only outdoor space.

photos.title: View from living quarters at 730 West Winnebago
photos.caption: The view from inside a home at 730 West Winnebago Street. What daily life looked like in a neighborhood the government would soon label 'Hazardous.'

photos.title: Rear of houses in 900 block West Clybourn Street
photos.caption: Rear view of houses on West Clybourn Street's 900 block. Back-of-house conditions factored heavily into HOLC grading.

photos.title: Milwaukee industrial waterfront
photos.caption: Milwaukee's industrial waterfront. The Menomonee Valley's factories employed thousands but their pollution lowered nearby property grades.

photos.title: Milwaukee neighborhood street
photos.caption: A quiet residential street in Milwaukee. Whether this block was graded A or D would determine mortgage access for decades.

photos.title: Workers near Milwaukee factory
photos.caption: Workers near a Milwaukee factory. HOLC appraisers noted the 'class' of residents as part of their neighborhood assessments.

photos.title: Milwaukee residential block
photos.caption: A full block of Milwaukee homes in 1936. Two years later, an appraiser would assign a single letter grade to determine its financial future.

photos.title: Children in Milwaukee neighborhood
photos.caption: Children in a Milwaukee neighborhood. The lines drawn on maps in 1938 would shape their opportunities for generations.

photos.title: Commercial street, Milwaukee
photos.caption: A commercial stretch in Milwaukee. Businesses in redlined zones would struggle for decades to get loans and investment.

photos.title: Wooden houses, Milwaukee residential area
photos.caption: Frame houses in a Milwaukee residential area. Wood-frame construction was noted as a negative factor in HOLC evaluations.

photos.title: Milwaukee residential street with cars
photos.caption: Cars line a Milwaukee residential street in 1936. The automobile age was reshaping cities — and so was federal mortgage policy.
